text:
Hey everyone :wave:
I've just started working with a software company that has a couple of target markets that I'm not too familiar with and could do with your help identifying some core persona info (e.g. problems, content/format preferences, hangouts) for the following audiences:
• CxOs (COO, Chief of Nursing)
• Compliance / Risk Managers
• Safety /EHS Officers
• HR/L&D Managers
• IT Managers / CIOs
We will do some proper research as soon as we've cleared a backlog of other things, but I need to get some quick guidance together so we can get started on creating content as we're starting a blog from scratch, so anything you can share to help me pull this together asap would be greatly appreciated - TIA :pray:

text: Hi Team, Can anyone refer a good email template for case study requests or suggest the necessary approach toward customers ?

text: Ghost is bleh :thumbsdown:  very limited and bare bones

elements.text: Ghost is bleh
very limited and bare bones

text:
From my experience with the companies I have worked in, most of this is done in-house. Unless of course, you need graphics on a daily basis or as your primary content.

It does take a little more time than what an expert graphic designer would, but it is a lot more economical. A paid subscription of <https://www.canva.com/|Canva> is all I need. Even the free tool did fine for some pieces. You can explore other tools too.

As long as instructions are clear and timelines are realistic, shouldn't be a problem managing it in-house.

text: Hey Sanjana! Here are my two bits. I think it’s always a great idea to speak to an SEO specialist before making a strategy. Find out what keywords they already rank on, if there are potential keywords they’d like to target etc. A conversation with an SEO specialist will throw up a lot of content gaps that you might want to address in your strategy.

elements.text: Hey Sanjana! Here are my two bits. I think it’s always a great idea to speak to an SEO specialist before making a strategy. Find out what keywords they already rank on, if there are potential keywords they’d like to target etc. A conversation with an SEO specialist will throw up a lot of content gaps that you might want to address in your strategy.

text:
Every c-suite person, risk manager, and IT manager I've known has been a middle aged man and older, with widely varying levels of education.
HR and compliance managers I've known have been white women in their (presumably) 20s with a bachelors degree.

text:
Adding onto the brilliant suggestions so far

• Take the webinar clips and add into the final blog post (google looks kindly on this)? - <https://www.go1.com/blog/post-how-to-improve-the-impact-of-management-training|blog example>
• Take the key takeaways and create a small email drip course
• Take a customer testimonial from the transcript and add to site, or part of a sales/marketing nurture lane
• Pull the audio only from the video clip and turn into an audiogram (eg animated captions only) - <https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6898998706537144321/|Linkedin example>
• Pull any of the video clips and add to Paid Social campaigns to drive to on-demand recap 
have a few more - but these are the main ones

text:
Hey folks, I lead a small team of freelance writers and im overwhelmed
With the amount of articles, not able
To find time to edit them all. I’d like to find a remote content editor, does anyone have experience have an editor work remotely? And how would you pay them, hourly? Per word? Monthly stipend?

elements.text:
Hey folks, I lead a small team of freelance writers and im overwhelmed
With the amount of articles, not able
To find time to edit them all. I’d like to find a remote content editor, does anyone have experience have an editor work remotely? And how would you pay them, hourly? Per word? Monthly stipend?

text: Hey Ben! I'm a remote freelance editor and most of my contracts have paid hourly, though I've also done a few that paid per piece or a monthly stipend if that's what the client preferred.

elements.text: Hey Ben! I'm a remote freelance editor and most of my contracts have paid hourly, though I've also done a few that paid per piece or a monthly stipend if that's what the client preferred.

text: Hi Ben! For editing clients, I would work on a retainer or hourly because the amount of time that goes into editing each piece can vary wildly even when you’re working with the same writers. Just my opinion and how I’ve done it in the past :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hi Ben! For editing clients, I would work on a retainer or hourly because the amount of time that goes into editing each piece can vary wildly even when you’re working with the same writers. Just my opinion and how I’ve done it in the past

text: Hey Ben. I’m a freelance editor and I usually go with a retainer. But some clients also pay hourly.

elements.text: Hey Ben. I’m a freelance editor and I usually go with a retainer. But some clients also pay hourly.

text:
Hey <@U031H7YAB7S> having SEO skills is key to building rock solid content strategy. Without SEO it is usually fluff. So my question to you is what do you mean by content strategy i.e what services do you offer to your customers?
Is it just limited to writing, proofing, execution and creative planning, concept creation for content led campaigns?

If yes, I'd ideally suggest two things (considering that as a client I would want my content to rank etc whatever be the format or creative angle.

1. *Find an SEO partner* - this person will do keyword research for you and you do the remaining as listed above. 
2. Find companies that have an in-house SEO team and are hiring freelancers to support production. 
You can frame it like:

1. I'd like to get detailed briefs including keyword research to deliver projects per your expectation. Is that possible?
Hope this helps! Happy to answer any questions -DM away
